response.reasoning: While 'voice over' is acceptable, 'voiceover' (one word) is the more common and preferred noun form in modern UK English.
'Live streaming' as two words is an acceptable noun phrase, though 'live-streaming' is also common.
'All of the' is grammatically correct and commonly used for emphasis or clarity, not an error.
The noun form 'try-outs' requires a hyphen in UK English.
The compound word 'mid-process' should be hyphenated.
The sentence requires the pronoun 'they' before 'receive' to be grammatically correct: 'as they receive feedback'.
As a compound adjective, 'thought-provoking' is generally hyphenated for clarity, even when used predicatively.
'href' is an HTML attribute and not an error in the visible document content.
'href' is an HTML attribute and not an error in the visible document content.
As a compound adjective modifying 'theme exploration', 'cross-cutting' requires a hyphen.
